repnme.cdata!:
Detailed implementation review : India
            health sector (2006-2007)

abstracts.cdata!:
This report summarizes the findings of a
            Detailed Implementation Review (DIR) of five Bank-financed
            projects in India: the Food and Drugs Capacity Building
            Project, the Orissa Health Systems Development Project; the
            Second National AIDS Control Project; the Malaria Control
            Project; and the Tuberculosis Control Project. The DIR is a
            strictly confidential internal World Bank document, the
            purpose of which is described herein. Its findings are of a
            highly sensitive and confidential nature and should not be
            used by the Government of India as the basis for initiating
            any administrative, criminal, or civil proceeding. The
            Government of India may wish to undertake its own
            investigation into matters raised by this DIR to determine
            whether any of the laws of India may have been violated.
            Moreover, the DIR should not be cited or referred to in the
            course of any Government of India investigation, in its
            investigation reports, or in any administrative, civil, or
            criminal proceedings undertaken by the Government of India
            related to the five projects reviewed in this report. This
            report is provided without prejudice to the World Banks
            privileges and immunities.

repnme.cdata!:
Detailed implementation review : India
            health sector (2006-2007)

abstracts.cdata!:
This report summarizes the findings of a
            Detailed Implementation Review (DIR) of five Bank-financed
            projects in India: the Food and Drugs Capacity Building
            Project, the Orissa Health Systems Development Project; the
            Second National AIDS Control Project; the Malaria Control
            Project; and the Tuberculosis Control Project. The DIR is a
            strictly confidential internal World Bank document, the
            purpose of which is described herein. Its findings are of a
            highly sensitive and confidential nature and should not be
            used by the Government of India as the basis for initiating
            any administrative, criminal, or civil proceeding. The
            Government of India may wish to undertake its own
            investigation into matters raised by this DIR to determine
            whether any of the laws of India may have been violated.
            Moreover, the DIR should not be cited or referred to in the
            course of any Government of India investigation, in its
            investigation reports, or in any administrative, civil, or
            criminal proceedings undertaken by the Government of India
            related to the five projects reviewed in this report. This
            report is provided without prejudice to the World Banks
            privileges and immunities.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Malaria Control Project
            for India were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: With the benefit of hindsight, the overall project
            was overambitious. The managerial capacity of the
            implementing agency was not given sufficient attention
            during project design. The monitoring and evaluation
            framework was not sufficiently developed. Task Teams and
            Management should be responsive to changing needs of the
            project and restructure accordingly. Suspension and
            restructuring of the project, though late, were crucial for
            the success of the project. Strong leadership is an
            important but not necessary condition for success. Nurturing
            ownership of states, which are at cutting edge of
            implementation, is critical for program success. Identifying
            and adequately addressing procurement and supply chain
            logistics up-front is critical for the success of the Vector
            Borne Disease Control Program (VBDCP). Strengthening program
            management at district and state levels is essential for
            successful decentralization. Program monitoring needs
            further strengthening by incorporating objectively
            verifiable process and output indicators and establishing a
            system of data triangulation by experts complemented by well
            targeted surveys and supportive supervision. Vector control
            measures need to be better integrated and of higher quality,
            and there is an urgent need to improve the vector
            surveillance. The introduction of Insecticide Treated
            Bednet, albeit late, was one of the most successful aspects
            of the project. Monitoring therapeutic efficacy of anti
            malaria drugs and insecticide resistance should be more rigorous.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Malaria Control, Orissa Health
            Systems Development, Tuberculosis Control, Women and Child
            Development, and Gujarat Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction
            Projects : proposed restructuring of five projects for polio eradication

abstracts.cdata!:
This report seeks the Executive
            Directors' approval to restructure five projects:
            Malaria Control Project (Cr. 29640-IN), the Orissa Health
            Systems Development Project (Cr. NO41 0-IN), the
            Tuberculosis Control Project (Cr. 29360-IN), the Women and
            Child Development Project (Cr. N0420-IN), and the Gujarat
            Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction Project (Cr. 36370-IN)
            The report proposes reallocating SDR 65.35 million
            (approximately US$ 96 million equivalent) of credit proceeds
            to support urgent financing needs for a polio eradication
            program in India. Two of these projects (Orissa Health
            Systems Development and Women and Child Development) are
            financed through Interim Trust Funds (ITF). Approval is
            being sought for these two projects through the
            International Development Association since ITF credits have
            become part of IDA'S general resources, and IDA may act
            for itself with regard to such resources rather than as
            administrator for ITF. The proposed restructuring will
            assist the Government of India in eradicating poliomyelitis
            from the country--this will contribute to global polio
            eradication, and supplement the ongoing Immunization
            Strengthening Project (Cr. 33400-IN) and the Supplemental
            Credit to this project (Cr. 33401-IN) by financing
            additional polio eradication activities required on an
            emergency basis by the Government of India. In all five
            projects, the proposed restructuring would neither
            compromise the original objectives nor affect their overall
            economic viability.

5081227.trustfund:
TF035379-INDIA - MALARIA CONTROL,TF034266-INDIA - MALARIA CONTROL PROJECT,TF022345-PHRD-LEPROSY,BLINDNESS,MALARIA
            & TB CONTROL,TF033596-INDIA - MALARIA PROJECT,TF034041-INDIA - HEALTH,TF036640-INDIA - PROPOSED SECOND
            HIV/AIDS, MALARIA CONTROL PROJECT,TF033079-INDIA - HEALTH

abstracts.cdata!:
The medium-term objective of the Malaria
            Control Project is to help India create an enhanced and more
            effective malaria control program that uses a better mix of
            effective malaria control interventions responsive to local
            needs; and strengthen the Directorate of the National
            Malaria Eradication Program (NMP) and modifies its
            orientation. The long-term objective is to reduce death,
            morbidity and social and economic losses from malaria. The
            project will include the following five components: 1) an
            integrated early detection and prompt treatment of clinical
            cases component; 2) a selective vector component; 3) a
            medicated mosquito net program component; 4) an epidemic
            response and intersectoral collaboration component; and 5)
            an institutional strengthening component.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Malaria Control Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment presents a
            management plan covering impacts arising from the types of
            hazardous chemicals used in the Malaria Control Project in
            India (insecticides, larvicides, and biocides, etc.), and
            out of their modes of application. Accidental release of
            organophosphorus insecticides into lakes, rivers, and other
            water bodies may exert toxic effects on fish and small
            aquatic organisms before degradation is complete. Carbamate
            insecticides generally are highly toxic to honeybees.
            Synthetic pyrethroid insecticides are highly toxic to both
            fish and honeybees. Mitigation measures arise from chemical
            use that is focally applied (selective areas); seasonally
            applied (limited to the seasons in which peak disease
            transmission or pest nuisance occurs); partially applied to
            selected resting sites (certain areas in the house); and
            partially applied to bed-nets, curtains, and traps. To avoid
            increasing health risks (vector resistance) and releasing
            insecticides into the environment resulting from improper
            insecticide use, several different insecticides in rotation
            are proposed. Further, vector control options available are
            to: use indoor residual spraying (where only the inner walls
            and roofs of houses are sprayed), take personal protection
            measures, and conduct larviciding. Appropriate precautions
            must be taken in the packaging, handling, and disposal of
            insecticides. To eliminate accidental release during
            transport and storage, local packaginghave to conform to
            government and internationally-accepted standards, and the
            empty containers should be treated as hazardous wastes. Date
            expired insecticides will be sent to a secure landfill.
            Wherever synthetic pyrethroids are used, care should be
            taken to avoid their spillage into surface water as these
            are extremely toxic to fish, and to avoid their release into
            places where honeybee cultivation is taking place. Local
            authorities responsible for distributing these insecticides
            should know about their chemical toxicity, and possess
            protective clothing and equipment, ensure clear and durable
            labeling on all packages depicting their hazardous nature.
            To discourage recycling of containers, the government should
            encourage manufacturers to use nonreusable containers.
            Spills generated during impregnation of bednets and curtains
            should be collected, and after mixing with the washings of
            the empty insecticide containers, need to be chemically
            destroyed in situ. Workers engaged in the impregnation
            operation should wear gloves and masks to avoid skin contact
            with insecticides and inhalation exposure.
